Description: Body sherd of Laconian pottery kylix; cream slip; interior glazed black with two groups of three narrow bands in added red; exterior: below offset rim (almost wholly lost), red between black bands; below, frieze of swans in silhouette to right (one with part of tail missing; red for eye and part of tail; part of tail of second, in red); below, three groups of three bands, upper ones in red; at bottom of sherd, tops of two rays.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Sherd finds parallels with a cup with conical foot in Queensland (Stibbe, 'Laconian Drinking Vases and other Open Shapes', 1989, Allard Pierson Series, p. 63, 167, pl. 12, no. 1-2). The sherd probably belongs to the same vase as Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.263.1894. Attributable to the Painter of the Taranto Fish.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GC.57) (phase 3)
